facts.text: Companies Profits Surtax Act, 1964 received assent of President on 2nd May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Act which received the assent of the President on 2nd May, 1964 is an Act to impose a special tax on the profits of certain companypanies.

facts.text: First assessment year under Act commences on 1st April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 4 of the Act a tax known as surtax become chargeable on every companypany for every assessment year companymencing on and from the 1st day of April 1964

facts.text: Previous year for first assessment: 1st April 1963 to 31st March 1964.

anchor.surface_text: In terms of s. 4 of the Act the first assessment year for the purpose of the Act in respect of the companypany was that companymencing on and from the first day of April, 1964. The previous year

facts.text: Capital computed as on first day of previous year relevant to assessment year i.e. 1st April 1963.

anchor.surface_text: the capital of the respondent as on the 1st day of April, 1963 in terms of rule 1 of the Second Schedule to the Companies  Profits  Surtax Act, 1964

facts.text: Appellant contends reserves created on 8th August 1963 should not be added to capital as on 1st April 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The sole companytention on behalf of the appellant is that these appropriations having been made on the 8th August, 1963 companyld number be treated as companyponents of capital as on the first day of the previous year i.e. 1-4-1963

facts.text: Court holds appropriations to reserves effective from 1st April 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Their determination to appropriate the sums mentioned to the three separate classes of reserves on the 8th August 1963 must be related to the 1st of April 1963 i.e. the beginning of the accounts for the new year and must be treated as effective from that day.

facts.text: Accounts made up to 31st March 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that the accounts of the companypany have to be made up for a year up to a particular day. In this case that day was the 31st March, 1963.

facts.text: Bombay High Court case: CIT Delhi v. Aryodaya Ginning Manufacturing Co. Ltd., profits year ended 31st December 1948.

facts.text: Surtax chargeable for assessment years commencing from 1st April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 4 of the Act a tax known as surtax become chargeable on every companypany for every assessment year companymencing on and from the 1st day of April 1964 in respect of so much of its chargeable profits

facts.text: Assessment year means period of twelve months commencing 1st April every year.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 3  assessment year means the period of twelve months companymencing on the 1st day of April of every year.

Under section 4 of the Act a tax known as surtax become chargeable on every company for every assessment year commencing on and from the 1st day of April 1964 in respect of so much of its chargeable profits of the previous year as exceeded the statutory deduction, at the rates specified in the Third Schedule.

concepts.unlisted_description: Imposes surtax on companies for assessment years from April 1 1964 on chargeable profits exceeding statutory deduction

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2(3) assessment year means the period of twelve months commencing on the 1st day of April of every year.

Chargeable profits is defined in S. 2(5) as the total income of an assessee companyputed under the Income-tax Act, 1961 for any previous year or years, as the case may be, and adjusted in accordance with the provisions of the First Schedule.

Statutory deductions, ignoring the provisos, means in terms of S. 2(8) an amount equal to 10 per cent of the capital of the company as computed in accordance with the provisions of the Second Schedule or an amount of Rs. 2,00,000/- whichever is greater.

Rule 1 of the Second Schedule with which alone we are concerned in this section reads Subject to the other provisions contained in this Schedule, the capital of a company shall be the aggregate of the amounts, as on the first day of the previous year relevant to the assessment year, of- its paid-up share capital its reserves, if any created under the proviso (b) to clause (vi-b) of sub- section (2) of section 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 (XI of 1922), or under subsection (3) of section 34 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 (LXIII of 1961) its other reserves as reduced by the amounts credited to such reserves as have been allowed as a deduction in computing the income of the company for the purposes of the Indian income-tax Act, 1922 (XI of 1922), or the Income-tax Act, 1961 (XLIII of 1961) its debentures, if any and any moneys borrowed by it from Government or the Industrial Finance Corporation of India or the Industrial Credit and Finance Corporation of India or any other financial institution which the Central Government may notify in this behalf in the Official Gazette or any banking institution (not being a financial institution notified as aforesaid) or any person in a country outside India Provided that such moneys are borrowed for the creation of a capital asset in India and the agreement under which such moneys are borrowed provides for the repayment thereof during a period of not less than seven years.

concepts.interpretation: Appropriations to reserves out of profits of the year ending 31st March 1963, though made on 8th August 1963, must be treated as effective from 1st April 1963, the first day of the previous year, and included in computation of capital.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation.-For the removal of doubts it is hereby declared that any amount standing to the credit of any account in the books of a company as on the first day of the previous year relevant to the assessment year which is of the nature of item (5) or item (6) or item (7) under the heading RESERVES AND SURPLUS or of any item under the heading CURRENT LIABILITIES AND PROVISIONS in the column relating to Liabilities in the Form of Balance-sheet given in Part I of Schedule VI to the Companies Act, 1956 (1 of 1956), shall not be regarded as a reserve

concepts.unlisted_label: Part I Schedule VI Companies Act 1956
concepts.unlisted_description: Form of balance-sheet for determining nature of reserves and liabilities

anchor.surface_text: The company was assessed to business profits tax chargeable under the Business Profits Tax Act for the accounting period 1st January to 31st March 1949 and the question which arose was what was the capital of the company- pany for the accounting period.

concepts.unlisted_description: Act under which similar capital computation issue arose in cited case

anchor.surface_text: Explanation.-For the removal of doubts it is hereby declared that any amount standing to the credit of any account in the books of a company as on the first day of the previous year relevant to the assessment year which is of the nature of item (5) or item (6) or item (7) under the heading RESERVES AND SURPLUS or of any item under the heading CURRENT LIABILITIES AND PROVISIONS in the column relating to Liabilities in the Form of Balance-sheet given in Part I of Schedule VI to the Companies Act, 1956 (1 of 1956), shall not be regarded as a reserve for the purposes of computation of the capital of a company under the provisions of this Schedule.

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation to Rule 1 Second Schedule Companies Profits Surtax Act 1964
concepts.unlisted_description: Clarifies amounts not to be regarded as reserves for capital computation

issues.text: whether three several sums appropriated by the Directors of the respondent towards reserves on the 8th August 1963 Gut of the profits of the year ending 31st March, 1963 should be added to other items for companyputation of the capital of the respondent as on the 1st day of April, 1963 in terms of rule 1 of the Second Schedule to the Companies Profits Surtax Act, 1964

anchor.surface_text: The question involved in this appeal is, whether three several sums appropriated by the Directors of the respondent towards reserves on the 8th August 1963 Gut of the profits of the year ending 31st March, 1963 should be added to other items for companyputation of the capital of the respondent as on the 1st day of April, 1963 i

arguments.claim: Appropriations to reserves made on 8th August 1963 could not be treated as components of capital as on 1st April 1963 in terms of rule 1 of the Second Schedule

anchor.surface_text: The sole contention on behalf of the appellant is that these appropriations having been made on the 8th August, 1963 could not be treated as components of capital as on the first day of the previous year i.e. 1-4-1963, in terms of rule 1 to the Second Schedule.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ii  and  iii  of rule 1 to the Second Schedule. The reserves in this case to which exception is being taken by the appellant as companyponents of th

arguments.court_reasoning: Appropriations relate back to 1st April 1963 due to accounting practices and nature of determination

arguments.claim: Appropriations could only be taken into consideration in the subsequent year from 1st April 1964 as on 1st April 1963 they formed part of undistributed profits with no earmarking

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General submitted that these could only be taken into consideration in the subsequent year commencing on the 1st of April 1964 on the ground that on the 1st of April 1963 they only formed a part of the mass of undistributed profits, no portion of which had been earmarked or set apart for any particular purpose.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the first of April 1963 and ended on the 31 st March, 1964. The capital of. the companypany in terms of rule 1 of the Second Schedule would be its pai

arguments.court_reasoning: Incorrect appreciation; accounts made up later but appropriation quality relates back

arguments.claim: Determination to appropriate reserves on 8th August 1963 must be related to and effective from 1st April 1963

anchor.surface_text: Their determination to appropriate the sums mentioned to the three separate classes of reserves on the 8th August 1963 must be related to the 1st of April 1963 i.e. the beginning of the accounts for the new year and must be treated as effective from that day.

arguments.claim: Delay in making up accounts and deciding appropriations after 1st April 1963 does not change the nature of appropriation which relates back

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that the accounts of the company have to be made up for a year up to a particular day. In this case that day was the 31st March, 1963. If it was reasonably practicable to make up the accounts up to the 31st March 1963... cannot make any difference to the nature or quality of the appropriation of the profits to reserves as determined by the directors after the first of April, 1963.

arguments.claim: In Aryodaya case, Bombay High Court held that resolutions on reserves had retrospective effect relating to profits and balance-sheet as on 31st December 1948

anchor.surface_text: A case very similar to the one before us came up for consideration before the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Aryodya Ginning Manufacturing Co. Ltd... The High Court observed that when one looked at the balance sheet of the year ended 31st December 1948 the amounts mentioned were shown respectively in the reserve fund and the dividend reserve fund...

arguments.claim: Madras High Court in Vasantha Mills dissented from Bombay HC view as no reserve until actual allocation by authority

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General referred to a judgment of the Madras High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Vasantha Mills Ltd. where the Madras High Court dissented from the view expressed by the Bombay High Court on the ground that there could be no reserve until there was allocation in fact by a person having the requisite authority to order that allocation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ctors was made on April 27, 1949 and a general meeting of the shareholders held on 27th June 1949 adopted the report and recommendation of the directo

arguments.court_reasoning: Allocation on later day treated effective from first day despite factual impossibility earlier

arguments.claim: Allocation on later day should be treated as effective from first day of year despite factual impossibility on that day

anchor.surface_text: In our view, although such allocation was factually not possible on the very first day of a year but allocation on a later day should be treated as effective from that day in view of the fact that the division of undistributed profits became effective from that day.

holdings.text: Their determination to appropriate the sums mentioned to the three separate classes of reserves on the 8th August 1963 must be related to the 1st of April 1963 i.e. the beginning of the accounts for the new year and must be treated as effective from that day.

anchor.surface_text: Their determination to appropriate the sums mentioned to the three separate classes of reserves on the 8th August 1963 must be related to the 1st of April 1963 i.e. the beginning of the accounts for the new year and must be treated as effective from that day.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appropriation out of profits for year ending 31 March 1963 relates back to commencement of previous year despite later formal decision due to accounting preparation time.

holdings.text: the fact that they could not do so for the simple reason that the calculation and collection of figures of all the items of income, expenditure of the company for the year ending March 31, 1963 was bound to take some time cannot make any difference to the nature or quality of the appropriation of the profits to reserves as determined by the directors after the first of April, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that the accounts of the company have to be made up for a year up to a particular day. In this case that day was the 31st March, 1963. If it was reasonably practicable to make up the accounts up to the 31st March 1963 and present the same to the directors of the respondent on April 1, 1963 they could have made up their minds on that day and declared their intention of appropriating the said and other sums to reserves of different kinds. But the fact that they could not do so for the simple reason that the calculation and collection of figures of all the items of income, expenditure of the company for the year ending March 31, 1963 was bound to take some time cannot make any difference to the nature or quality of the appropriation of the profits to reserves as determined by the directors after the first of April, 1963.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Practical delay in finalizing accounts does not alter the character of appropriations made from those profits as reserves effective from start of accounting period.

holdings.text: although such allocation was factually not possible on the very first day of a year but allocation on a later day should be treated as effective from that day in view of the fact that the division of undistributed profits became effective from that day.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, although such allocation was factually not possible on the very first day of a year but allocation on a later day should be treated as effective from that day in view of the fact that the division of undistributed profits became effective from that day.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if factually impossible on first day, later allocation deemed effective retrospectively because it divides undistributed profits starting from that day; prefers Bombay HC over Madras HC.

It is well known that the accounts of the company have to be made up for a year up to a particular day. In this case that day was the 31st March, 1963. If it was reasonably practicable to make up the accounts up to the 31st March 1963 and present the same to the directors of the respondent on April 1, 1963 they could have made up their minds on that day and declared their intention of appropriating the said and other sums to reserves of different kinds. But the fact that they could not do so for the simple reason that the calculation and collection of figures of all the items of income, expenditure of the company for the year ending March 31, 1963 was bound to take some time cannot make any difference to the nature or quality of the appropriation of the profits to reserves as determined by the directors after the first of April, 1963.

In our view, although such allocation was factually number possible on the very first day of a year but allocation on a later day should be treated as effective from that day in view of the fact that the division of undistributed profits

In our view, although such allocation was factually not possible on the very first day of a year but allocation on a later day should be treated as effective from that day in view of the fact that the division of undistributed profits became effective from that day.
